snippet: In so-called U-turn transactions before 2008, global banks like Standard Chartered could provide scant information on transfers that passed in and out of the United States.
abstract: List of global banks that have been accused in recent years of laundering foreign transactions totaling billions of dollars has been growing, now including Standard Chartered; accused banks took advantage of a law that was not changed until 2008 and that allowed banks to disguise client identities and move their money offshore; cases show just how much activity with Iran was permitted.

byline.original: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and EDWARD WYATT

lead_paragraph: In so-called U-turn transactions before 2008, global banks like Standard Chartered could provide scant information on transfers that passed in and out of the United States.

headline.seo: How a Lax Banking Law Obscured Money Flow
headline.main: In Laundering Case, a Lax Banking Law Obscured Money Flow
headline.print_headline: A Lax Banking Law Obscured Money Flow
